newsitem.title: USA: Williams net pressured by interest costs.
newsitem.headline: Williams net pressured by interest costs.

text.p: Interest costs were the major reason Williams Cos Inc first quarter earnings fell short of analysts' expectations, spokesman Jim Gipson said.
Interest on the debt incurred in the company's expansion of its telecommunications operations was one of the things that limited gains above 1996's record results, he told Reuters.
"Business fundamentals are really solid," Gipson said Friday, adding the company expects "another good year."
"We're pleased to start the year in a way that will help us achieve our goals for 1997," was the way chief executive Keith E. Bailey put it when the company reported Thursday.

"In order to hit the aggressive targets we have established, all of our businesses must raise their level of performance -- and we must continue to expand in ways that improve the bottom line," he continued.
Williams reported profits of $0.64 per share for the March quarter, up from the $0.63 earned in 1996's initial quarter but short of the First Call consensus estimate of $0.68.
Increased interest reduced earnings by $0.03, Gipson said.

He also noted the company reported a decline in energy commodity trading operating profits to $16.5 million in the latest quarter from $21.8 million a year earlier and said this was due to lower volatility in the natural gas market.
Petroleum Services, the unit which includes Williams' interstate petroleum products pipeline, first quarter operating profit declined to $14.4 million from $17.8 million.
The decrease primarily was due to a four percent decline in shipments, shorter average hauls and higher operating expenses within the products pipeline business, the company said.
Gipson said this was due to the economy in the upper Midwest areas served by the pipeline and weather that delayed spring planting.

The company reported a $2 million communications group operating loss compared with an operating profit of $2.8 million in 1996's first quarter, saying the change "was due to the expense of the previously disclosed commitment by management to expand the infrastructure of this business."
Gipson said Williams has said it expects 1997 to be another building year for its communications unit.

The company cited the April 10 announcement that Williams and Northern Telecom Ltd will combine customer premise equipment sales and service operations as an example of this effort, adding "this transaction is expected to close within two months and be additive to earnings."
The company said all three of its interstate natural gas pipelines had increased first quarter operating profits.
